bank.prompt: Explain how prices function as an allocative mechanism in a market economy. Use one example.
mark_scheme: Defines allocative role of prices (signals scarcity/preferences)
Explains incentive effects on consumers (rationing) and producers (profit signal)
bank.model_answer: Prices coordinate decisions by signalling relative scarcity and consumer preferences. When a good becomes scarcer, its price tends to rise, which rations demand (some consumers reduce consumption) and incentivises producers to increase supply or reallocate resources towards that market. For example, a rise in coffee prices after a poor harvest reduces quantity demanded and encourages suppliers to source alternatives or expand production elsewhere.

bank.prompt: Distinguish between (i) a movement along the demand curve and (ii) a shift of the demand curve. Give one cause of each.
mark_scheme: Movement along demand: change in quantity demanded due to own-price change
Shift of demand: change in demand due to non-price determinant
bank.model_answer: A movement along the demand curve occurs when the good’s own price changes, causing quantity demanded to change. A shift of the demand curve occurs when a non-price determinant (e.g., income, tastes, prices of substitutes/complements) changes, altering demand at every price. For example, a price fall causes movement; higher income for a normal good shifts demand right.

bank.prompt: Explain why price elasticity of demand matters for firms when setting prices.
mark_scheme: Links elasticity to total revenue/profit implications
Explains elastic vs inelastic pricing effect on TR
bank.model_answer: Elasticity determines how strongly quantity demanded responds to price changes, which affects total revenue. With elastic demand, raising price reduces total revenue because the quantity fall is proportionally larger; with inelastic demand, raising price can increase total revenue. Firms use this to choose price strategies and predict sales, especially when margins and competition are important.

bank.prompt: Explain two effects of a binding minimum price (price floor).
mark_scheme: Identifies surplus (Qs>Qd) at the floor price
Explains consequences (waste, storage, black markets, unemployment depending on market)
bank.model_answer: A binding price floor set above equilibrium creates excess supply (a surplus) because producers supply more while consumers demand less. This can lead to unsold output, pressure for government purchases, or non-price rationing. It may also encourage informal markets or quality reductions as sellers compete without lowering the legal price.

bank.prompt: Define market equilibrium and explain what happens when the market price is above the equilibrium price.
mark_scheme: Defines equilibrium as Qd=Qs at price P*
bank.model_answer: Market equilibrium occurs where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied at the equilibrium price. If price is above equilibrium, quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded, creating a surplus. Sellers face unsold stock, which tends to push prices down (or triggers discounting) until equilibrium is restored.

bank.prompt: The government introduces a regulation that increases production costs in the steel industry. At the same time, construction demand rises due to public infrastructure spending. Explain: (a) supply curve change, (b) demand curve change, (c) effect on equilibrium price, (d) effect on equilibrium quantity, (e) which effect may dominate and why.
mark_scheme: Supply shifts left/up due to higher costs
Demand shifts right due to higher construction demand
Price likely increases (both shifts push price up)
Quantity is ambiguous (depends on relative magnitudes)
Explains dominance using relative shift sizes/elasticities
bank.model_answer: Higher production costs shift supply left (or up), reducing supply at every price. Higher construction activity increases demand, shifting demand right. Both changes tend to raise equilibrium price. The effect on equilibrium quantity is ambiguous because demand raises quantity while the supply contraction reduces it; the net outcome depends on which shift is larger and on elasticities.

bank.prompt: A government introduces a tax on cigarettes. Demand is highly inelastic. Explain: (a) who bears most of the tax burden, (b) what happens to consumer price, (c) what happens to quantity traded, (d) why elasticity determines incidence, (e) link to prices as an allocative mechanism.
mark_scheme: Consumers bear most burden when demand is inelastic
Elasticity explains ability to adjust quantity/avoid tax
Links to price signals/incentives and resource allocation
bank.model_answer: With highly inelastic demand, consumers reduce quantity only slightly when price rises, so they bear most of the tax burden via a higher price paid. Quantity traded falls a little. Elasticity determines incidence because the less responsive side cannot easily avoid the tax through changing behaviour. The higher price still signals the good’s increased ‘cost’ to society, discouraging consumption at the margin and influencing allocation.

bank.prompt: Initial equilibrium: P* = £10, Q* = 100. A subsidy to producers is introduced. State: (a) which curve shifts, (b) direction, (c) new equilibrium price relative to £10, (d) new equilibrium quantity relative to 100, (e) effect on consumer surplus (direction only).
bank.model_answer: A producer subsidy reduces effective costs, shifting supply right (down). The equilibrium consumer price falls below £10, equilibrium quantity rises above 100, and consumer surplus increases due to lower price and higher quantity.

bank.prompt: Distinguish between (i) a movement along the supply curve and (ii) a shift of the supply curve. Give one cause of each.
mark_scheme: Movement along supply: change in quantity supplied due to own-price change
Shift of supply: change due to non-price determinant (costs/tech/taxes)
bank.model_answer: A movement along the supply curve occurs when the market price changes, leading firms to change quantity supplied. A shift occurs when a non-price factor changes, such as input costs, technology, or taxes. For example, a higher market price causes movement; higher energy costs shift supply left.

bank.prompt: Explain what determines whether consumers or producers bear more of an indirect tax.
mark_scheme: Tax incidence depends on relative elasticities of demand and supply
More inelastic side bears more burden
bank.model_answer: Tax incidence depends on relative price elasticities: the more inelastic side of the market bears a larger share of the tax burden because it cannot adjust quantity much in response to the price wedge. If demand is inelastic relative to supply, consumers bear more; if supply is inelastic relative to demand, producers bear more.

bank.prompt: Define consumer surplus and producer surplus, and explain how a fall in price affects each (direction only).
mark_scheme: Defines consumer surplus and producer surplus
bank.model_answer: Consumer surplus is the difference between what consumers are willing to pay and what they actually pay. Producer surplus is the difference between the price producers receive and the minimum price they would accept. A fall in price increases consumer surplus and reduces producer surplus, all else equal.

bank.prompt: Give one reason why governments intervene in markets and briefly explain how intervention can affect allocation.
mark_scheme: One valid rationale (externalities, information failure, market power)
bank.model_answer: Governments may intervene due to externalities, where private decisions do not reflect social costs or benefits. A tax on a negative externality raises the price, reducing quantity demanded and reallocating resources away from harmful production/consumption, improving allocative outcomes from a social perspective.

bank.prompt: State two differences between perfect competition and monopoly.
mark_scheme: Perfect competition: many firms, price takers, free entry; monopoly: one firm, price maker, barriers
bank.model_answer: Perfect competition has many firms, homogeneous products, and free entry, so firms are price takers. Monopoly has a single dominant firm protected by high barriers to entry, giving it price-setting power.

bank.prompt: A city introduces a rent control (price ceiling) below the market equilibrium. Explain: (a) shortage/surplus outcome, (b) non-price rationing mechanisms, (c) likely long-run effects on housing quality/supply, (d) who benefits and who loses, (e) link to allocative role of prices.
mark_scheme: Links to distorted price signals and allocation
bank.model_answer: A binding rent ceiling creates a shortage because quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied. Allocation then occurs through non-price rationing (waiting lists, informal payments, discrimination). Over time, landlords may reduce maintenance or exit the market, reducing quality and supply. Some incumbent tenants gain, while prospective renters lose. Prices no longer signal scarcity, so resources are misallocated.

bank.prompt: The price of tea rises sharply (tea is a substitute for coffee). Meanwhile, a disease reduces coffee crop yields. Explain the combined effects on the coffee market equilibrium price and quantity, and justify using demand/supply shifts.
mark_scheme: Tea price ↑ shifts coffee demand right
Coffee yield ↓ shifts coffee supply left
Quantity ambiguous; depends on shift magnitudes
bank.model_answer: A rise in tea’s price shifts coffee demand right as consumers substitute toward coffee. A fall in coffee yields shifts supply left. Both shifts increase equilibrium price. The equilibrium quantity is ambiguous because demand increases quantity while supply contraction decreases it; the net depends on which shift is larger.

bank.prompt: Initial equilibrium: P* = £5, Q* = 200. A per-unit tax is imposed on sellers. State: (a) which curve shifts, (b) direction, (c) what happens to price paid by buyers, (d) what happens to price received by sellers, (e) what happens to equilibrium quantity (direction).
bank.model_answer: A per-unit seller tax shifts supply left/up (equivalently, creates a wedge between buyer and seller prices). Buyers pay a higher price, sellers receive a lower net price, and the traded quantity falls.

bank.prompt: A price rises from £10 to £12 and quantity demanded falls from 100 to 90. Calculate PED using the midpoint method and interpret (elastic/inelastic).
What is non-price rationing? Give one example in a market with a price ceiling.
mark_scheme: Defines allocation mechanism other than price
Links to shortages under price ceiling
Provides a valid example (queues, waiting lists, discrimination)
bank.model_answer: Non-price rationing occurs when goods are allocated by methods other than price, often when a binding price ceiling creates shortages. Examples include queues, waiting lists, or landlords selecting tenants using strict criteria rather than raising rent.

bank.prompt: Define fixed costs and variable costs and give one example of each.
mark_scheme: Defines fixed costs (do not vary with output in short run)
bank.model_answer: Fixed costs do not change with output in the short run (e.g., factory rent). Variable costs vary with output (e.g., raw materials or hourly labour).

bank.prompt: State two features of monopolistic competition.
mark_scheme: Some price-setting power, low barriers to entry (any two)
bank.model_answer: Monopolistic competition has many firms and differentiated products, so each firm has some price-setting power. Entry barriers are relatively low, allowing new firms to enter in the long run.

bank.prompt: Explain briefly how the price mechanism responds to scarcity and how this affects resource allocation.
mark_scheme: Higher price rations demand and incentivises supply
Resources move toward higher-price (higher value) uses
bank.model_answer: When a good becomes scarcer, its price rises. The higher price reduces quantity demanded and encourages producers to increase supply, guiding resources toward producing the scarcer good. This reallocation happens because prices signal relative scarcity and profitability.

bank.topic: Price floor in labour market (minimum wage)
bank.prompt: A minimum wage is set above the equilibrium wage in a competitive labour market. Explain: (a) what happens to labour demanded and supplied, (b) the likely outcome (surplus/shortage), (c) who benefits and who loses, (d) one possible unintended consequence, (e) link to allocative role of prices.
mark_scheme: Labour demanded falls; labour supplied rises
Benefits employed workers at higher wage; harms unemployed/low-skill entrants and firms
Unintended consequence (informal work, reduced hours, substitution to capital)
bank.model_answer: A binding minimum wage above equilibrium reduces labour demanded and increases labour supplied, creating excess supply of labour (unemployment). Those who keep jobs benefit from higher wages, while some workers (especially low-productivity entrants) may be priced out. Firms face higher costs and may reduce hours or substitute capital. The wage no longer clears the market, so allocation via price is distorted.

bank.prompt: A city increases public transport fares by 10%. Demand is elastic. Explain the expected impact on (a) quantity demanded, (b) total revenue, and (c) how this informs pricing strategy. Link to the role of prices.
mark_scheme: Elastic demand: quantity falls by more than 10% (proportionally)
Pricing strategy: avoid fare increase or improve service/segment pricing
bank.model_answer: With elastic demand, a 10% fare increase leads to a more-than-proportional fall in quantity demanded, so total revenue likely decreases. This suggests fare rises may be counterproductive unless elasticity changes (e.g., fewer substitutes) or quality improves. Prices guide consumer choices; higher prices discourage use and reallocate demand toward substitutes.

bank.prompt: Initial equilibrium: P* = £20, Q* = 50. Consumer income rises and the good is normal. State: (a) which curve shifts, (b) direction, (c) new equilibrium price relative to £20, (d) new equilibrium quantity relative to 50, (e) what happens to total revenue (directional, assuming demand is not perfectly elastic/inelastic).
mark_scheme: Total revenue tends to rise when both P and Q rise (general direction)
bank.model_answer: Income growth for a normal good shifts demand right. Equilibrium price rises above £20 and equilibrium quantity rises above 50. With both P and Q higher, total revenue generally increases (holding other factors constant).
